note.p: Title (Poems [1891])—W. G. Collingwood gave the title “The Alps from Schaffhausen” to this poem, which is untitled in the MS VIII manuscript. He failed to signal this editorial intervention by placing the title in square brackets; instead, confusingly, he preceded this poem with another, which Ruskin did entitle in the MS VIII draft, naming it "Schaffhausen", but which Collingwood renames "Entrance to Schaffhausen" and does signal his intervention by enclosing that title in square brackets.

Judging by the content of the poem, it would appear that Collingwood identified its subject correctly in his title. If the poem is represented in Ruskin's List of Additional Proposed Contents, it perhaps belongs under the heading “The Alps”, between the headings "Schaffhausen" and "The fall of the Rhine". It is unclear whether the titles in the list represent section headings or individual poems and essays to be included within sections--or both--but the verse fragment in MS VIII that Ruskin entitled "Schaffhausen" seems to dramatize a scene similar to that described in "There is a charmed peace that aye" ["The Alps from Schaffhausen"].
